user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_reset:
```c
_MHD_static_inline void
digest_reset (struct DigestAlgorithm *da)
{
  mhd_assert (! da->uninitialised);
  mhd_assert (da->algo_selected);
  mhd_assert (! da->hashing);
#ifdef MHD_MD5_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_MD5 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
#else  /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#endif /* ! MHD_MD5_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_MD5_reset (&da->ctx.md5_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_MD5_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA256 == da->algo)
  {
#ifdef MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
#else  /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    mhd_assert (da->ready_for_hashing);
#endif /* ! MHD_SHA256_HAS_FINISH */
    MHD_SHA256_reset (&da->ctx.sha256_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif /* _DEBUG */
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA256_SUPPORT */
#ifdef MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT
  if (MHD_DIGEST_BASE_ALGO_SHA512_256 == da->algo)
  {
    mhd_assert (! da->ready_for_hashing);
    MHD_SHA512_256_init (&da->ctx.sha512_256_ctx);
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = true;
#endif
  }
  else
#endif /* MHD_SHA512_256_SUPPORT */
  {
#ifdef _DEBUG
    da->ready_for_hashing = false;
#endif
    mhd_assert (0); /* May not happen, bad algorithm */
  }
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no explicit compiler language extensions in the provided code fragment. Specifically:
- There are no compiler-specific keywords or tokens present such as __attribute__, __asm, __asm__, __inline__, __typeof__, __builtin_*, __declspec, __extension__, or other vendor-specific extensions.
- The identifier _MHD_static_inline is just a macro identifier in the source; its expansion (which might contain an extension) is not shown here, so it cannot be treated as an explicit use of a compiler extension in this fragment.
- Conditional compilation (#ifdef / #endif) and the placement of preprocessor conditionals around else/if blocks are standard preprocessor usage, not language extensions.
- Use of identifiers like _DEBUG or names beginning with an underscore are reserved by the implementation but are not compiler language extensions per se and thus do not trigger Rule 1.2 by themselves.
- Calls to MHD_MD5_reset, MHD_SHA256_reset, mhd_assert, and use of true/false are ordinary identifiers/macros or standard C boolean usage (true/false require stdbool.h but are not compiler extensions in the code shown).

To flag a suspicious fragment under Rule 1.2 I would need explicit extension syntax visible in the code (e.g. __attribute__((...)), __asm, __builtin_..., __inline__ used as a language extension, pragmas specific to a compiler, etc.). None of those appear in the provided snippet.
